{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Use Indian English|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox royalty | image = Krishna orders Mayasura to build a palace for the Pandavas.jpg | alt = Mayasura | caption = Krishna requests Mayasura build a palace for the Pandavas | succession = King of [[Khandava Forest]] | predecessor = [[Takshaka]] | father = [[Kashyapa]] | mother = [[Diti]] | spouse = Hema | born = Sri Lanka | issue = [[Mandodari]] (foster daughter) }} In [[Hindu mythology]], '''Maya''' ({{lang-sa|मय}}), or '''Mayāsura''' ({{lang|sa|मयासुर}}) was a great ancient king of the [[asura]]s, [[daitya]]s and [[rakshasa|rākṣasa]] races. Maya was known for his brilliant architecture. In ''[[Mahabharatha]]'', Mayasabha – the hall of illusions – was named after him.
== In the ''Mahabharata'' == Mayasura had befriended a snake named [[Takshaka]] and lived with him in the area of [[Khandavprastha]] along with his family and friends but when the [[Pandavas]] came there after the partition of [[Hastinapur]], [[Arjuna|Arjun]] burnt the entire forest, forcing [[Takshaka]] to flee away and killing everyone in the forest. So, Mayasura decided to surrender to the [[Pandavas]]. [[Krishna]] was ready to forgive him and for this act, Mayasura built a very grand palace named Maya-Mahal, where the [[Pandavas]] would perform the [[Rajasuya|Rajsuya Yagna]]. He also offers him gifts like, a [[Bow and arrow|bow]], a [[sword]] and many more. He also gave a [[Gada (mace)|mace]] to Arjuna's brother [[Bhima]].
== In the ''Ramāyana'' == In Ramayana he is said to be the son of [[Daksha]]'s daughter, [[Diti]] (wife of [[Kashyapa]], a Saptaṛṣi).<ref>Uttara Ramayana https://archive.org/stream/TheRamayanaUttaraKandam/The_Ramayana_djvu.txt</ref> He is the husband of Hema<ref>P. G. Lalye (2008). ''Curses and boons in the Vālmīki Rāmāyaṇa''.</ref> and the foster father of [[Mandodari]], the beautiful wife of [[Ravana]], King of [[Lanka]].<ref name=tm>{{cite book|title=Tourism Marketing|author=Devahish Dasgupta|publisher=Pearson Education India|year=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oXWAEjcG-FsC|accessdate=29 January 2012|ISBN=978-81-317-3182-6|page=20}}</ref>
